description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 International Center of Diarrhoeal Disease Research, Bangladesh (icddr,b) är ett internationellt center som producerar forskning av stor relevans och av god kvalitet. Namnet till trots bedrivs forskning på diverse områden utöver just de viktiga diarrésjukdomarna, inkluderandes mödra- och spädbarnshälsa.
Insatsen avser programstöd under perioden 2016-2020 till icddr,b. Det föreslagna stödet är en fortsättning på tidigare stöd, vilket förlängdes med aktivitetsperiod till 30 juni 2016. Det föreslagna totala beloppet är 30 500 000 SEK för perioden 2016-2020. Stödet från Sida är programstöd till kapacitetsökning hos unga forskare i enlighet med deras Strategiska Plan 2015-2018, vilket är en förutsättning för den flexibilitet som krävs för att kunna anpassa aktiviteterna efter behov och erfarenhet. Sida är för närvarande den enda givaren som stödjer denna del av strategin specifikt.
Icddr,b har målsättningen att utveckla lösningar inom hälsa som är kostnadseffektiva och realistiska för fattiga människor som lever i låginkomstmiljöer. Icddr,b är idag ett framstående center för forskning av global relevans, exempelvis barn- och mödravård samt reproduktiv hälsa. De arbetar utifrån ett starkt rättighetsperspektiv och ställer den fattiga människan i centrum för sitt arbete. De planerar och investerar i långsiktiga hälsoinsatser och har en rådgivande funktion inom bla WHO.
icddr,b har utvecklat många processer och produkter av stor betydelse för hälsa i låginkomstmiljöer, till exempel ett världsledande koleravaccin och vätskeersättningen ORS. Nyligen har de tagit fram en enkel-dos av koleravaccinet, en lågkostnads-luftpump för småbarn med lunginflammation och stelkrampsvaccin för nyfödda.
Målsättningarna i icddr,b's Strategiska Plan 2015-2018 är att bli ett världsledande center inom forskning på global hälsa, och att bygga en bättre och effektivare finansiellt hållbar institution.
De fem strategiska prioriteringarna är: 1. Minska mödra- och spädbarnsdödlighet 2. Förebygga och behandla undernäring hos mödrar och barn 3. Kontroll av enteriska- och luftvägsinfektioner 4. Upptäcka och förebygga nya och återkommande infektionssjukdomar 5. Uppnå allmän/universell sjukvårdsförsäkring
Utöver dessa fem områden, där icddr,b är internationellt konkurrenskraftiga, vill man bygga upp starkare kapacitet inom områdena: hälsoeffekter av klimatförändringar, samt förebyggande och behandling av icke smittsamma sjukdomar. I Bangladesh har man en unik möjlighet att studera just kopplingen mellan hälsa och klimatförändringar.
Det svenska stödet är inte stort jämfört med de riktade forskningsanslag som centret attraherar, men det svenska forskningsstödet ger ett stort mervärde och kan anses katalytiskt. Ägarskapet för insatsen ligger i linje med centrets strategiska plan. Då majoriteten av forskningsmedel är öronmärkta av finansiärerna är det föreslagna svenska stödet av största vikt för centret då det möjliggör långsiktiga satsningar som följer centrets egna prioriteringar. Fokus ligger på återväxten av framtida starka forskningsledare på centret – något som dels möjliggör icddr,b’s framtid, dels stärker forskningsområdet i sig. Sida kan göra störst skillnad genom ett flerårigt stöd som möjliggör en satsning på unga lovande forskare, vilka annars har svårt att få extern finansiering i konkurrens med etablerade seniora forskare. Dessa unga lovande forskare välj ut i konkurrens och måste vara anställda som forskare vid icddr,b och vara under 40 år. Stödet kommer även att gå till etableringen av icddr,b’s genomikfacilitet vilken initierades med svenskt stöd under 2015-2016.
Sida har gett finansiellt stöd till icddr,b sedan 1981 och har erfarenheten att centret har god kapacitet att uppnå sina mål.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The International Centre for Diarrhoeal Disease Research, Bangladesh (icddr,b) is an international health research institution located in Dhaka, dedicated to addressing the health challenges that disproportionately affect people living in poverty in Bangladesh and other low- and middle-income countries. Sida has supported icddr,b since 1981, and the institute has evolved considerably over time. The institute is today a centre of excellence producing research of global relevance, such as child and maternal health, including reproductive health. Icddr,b provides unique opportunities to address health challenges in low-income settings through low-cost, practical, lifesaving solutions. The track record includes the oral rehydration solution (ORS), zinc for diarrhoea treatment and tetanus vaccines for newborns, which have saved and continue to save millions of lives worldwide. icddr,b has the capacity to undertake a full spectrum of research spanning population-based studies and demographic surveillance, large-scale clinical trials, hospital-based clinical studies, and laboratory research. icddr,b has recently had some turbulent years with concerns of both organizational nature and regarding research sustainability, especially with regards to the regrowth of researchers at the senior level. These challenges are being addressed in different ways and the institute is currently at a transitional stage.icddr,b’s Strategic Plan 2015-2018 reinforces icddr,b’s legacy of focusing not just on discovery, but also on strengthening the organisation’s ability to shape policy at the national, regional and global level, as well as advocating for the use of highly effective products and evidence-based discoveries. icddr,b reinforces these efforts through publishing and South-South collaboration, training and capacity-building, and continues to build a cadre of public health experts and capacities for low- and middle-income countries. In addition, strategic national, regional and global partnerships tap into the complementary assets of other organisations—academic, scientific, NGOs and private sector—to maximise the influence and reach of icddr,b’s work.There are five key areas in which icddr,b has a strong track record and expertise (points 1-5 below) and two which are highly relevant to Bangladesh and where icddr,b would like to develop greater expertise (points 6-7 below):1 Reduce maternal and neonatal mortality2 Prevent and treat maternal and childhood malnutrition 3 Control enteric and respiratory infections 4 Detect and control emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases5 Achieve universal health coverage6 Non Communicable Diseases7 Climate ChangeAn important value of the Sida research support is the earmarking of research project funding to younger scientists and a possibility to plan a career development program of several years in a row. Another added value according to icddr,b is the relationship to Sida also as advisors, not just funders, who can support in developing processes and criteria for the calls and experience-sharing in capacity building. Sida strongly supports the ownership of icddr,b and collaboration with both South and North, which increases the potential of icddr,b researchers to attract international funding and hence the basis for icddr,b's sustainability.

Research support
The main objective of the ongoing contribution is the development of skills and competencies of scientific staff; with a special focus on local junior researchers at mid-level, through a capacity training program. The participants are selected in competition and will go through a career development program including running their own research projects. In 2018 another component was added, for the study of an improved treatment of small children with severe pneumonia in Ethiopia. The method has been developed at icddr,b and is used at the hospital of icddr,b. The long-term purpose is to change the global guidelines of this treatment.
Strategic programme support
This component is a continuation of last year's strategic funding to enable icddr,b to enhance their activities of particular relevance to public health interventions that are linked to Water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH), Anti-microbial resistance (AMR), Climate change-related health impacts and Non-communicable diseases (NCDs) in urban slum populations - with global added value.
Expected outputs are: A series of theoretically based indicators that bear on vulnerability and well being of the urban poor, related directly and indirectly to the topics of WASH, AMR, NCDs, CCH and COVID-19; A series of measurement tools, equipment, and techniques to support the measurement of risk factors, exposures, and health outcomes in the urban poor; and Hardware and software to support the collection curation and communication of research data which will support project management within icddr,b and as part of broader South-South collaborations. The contribution will also support development of systems thinking in icddr,b.
The proposal is assessed relevant for Sida, and Sweden's Global Strategy for sustainable social development 20182022 as these fit into icddrb's strategy and longer term aspirations which include:
1. Promoting South-South collaboration and increasing engagement with the private sector. 2. Bringing icddr,bs current innovations to scale and increase uptake in Bangladesh and globally. 3. Building on its interdisciplinary capacity to examine the health consequences of climate change. 4. Preventing and treating non-communicable diseases 5. Continuing developing WASH and hygiene practices

description.narrative:
The past year has been intense at icddr,b, both in the light of the still ongoing pandemic and as there is a new Executive Director. The new ED is Dr Tahmeed Ahmed, a scientist who has been with the center since his graduation 30 years ago. There is a lot of pride in the country to finally have a Bangladeshi as ED. In 2020 icddr,b celebrated its 60 years anniversary.
The pandemic has had an important impact on activities at icddr,b; both providing research and funding opportunities, and challenges in pursuing research when health care staff engaged at the clinic more than at the laboratories, lock-downs, and an important shortfall due to both disease and deaths. Icddr,b offered covid-19 related health care to staff and their families and many of their staff supported the national system directly as health care providers and as experts at national and subnational level (i.e. Ministry of Health). At the end of 2021 there were 70 ongoing research studies related to Covid-19 at icddr,b. A Covid-19 response team was formed early 2020, comprising virologists, epidemiologists, clinicians, immunologists, emerging infection experts, and communication experts. Icddr,b has several agreements with various vaccine producers to conduct phase III trials in Bangladesh, to understand how a vaccine works on the population in a country like Bangladesh. Icddr,b has also been active in Covid-19 diagnostics, conducting over 100 000 tests in 2020 alone. One of icddr,bs senior scientists, Dr Firdausi Qadri (an important collaborator of Swedish researchers) is now a member of WHOs Strategic Advisory Group of Experts on Immunization (SAGE), who review vaccines, amongst those, vaccines against Covid-19.
At the same time, a lot of other activities have been ongoing. In the beginning of 2020, 1,2 million residents of Dhaka and another 1 million Rohingya people who sought refugee in Bangladesh and their host communities were vaccinated with the cholera vaccine. Importantly, there has still not been any cholera outbreaks in the camps, which is most certainly thanks to the vaccination campaigns as the area is a cholera endemic spot.
Overall, 443 original papers were published by icddr,b researchers, and there were 34 455 citations 2016-2019. In total there were 420 ongoing projects at icddr,b in 2020 and 201 international collaborations. There were 264 national and 274 international policy review committees with icddr,b representation.
An example of icddr,b relevance on a global scale is their invention soapy water, which made it to WHOs interim guideline on Water, sanitation, hygiene, and waste management for SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes C19. Soapy water is a low-cost alternative to bar soap. Another example is their contributions to the revision of WHOs SDG target 3.2 recommendations for newborn children. Icddr,b has also developed a low-cost and environment-friendly menstrual absorbent (Sultana-icddr,b Reusable Cloth pad). Girls in low-income countries lack menstrual hygiene management, contributing to 30% of school absence among menstruating girls. The icddr,b pad demonstrated 8% reduction in school absenteeism due to menstruation in rural and urban Bangladesh. 83% of the girls used and liked the pad, and girls and women were willing to pay for the technology.
In 2021, icddr,bs senior scientist Dr Firdausi Qadri was awarded the 2021 Ramon Magsaysay Award, often cited as Asias Nobel Prize. Dr Qadri is also a laureate of the 2020 LOréal-Unesco For Women in Science Award for her advocacy of early diagnoses and global vaccination as well as her work on understanding and preventing infectious diseases affecting children in developing countries.
Selected results from the Sida-funded projects 2020:
1. Research Support (FORSK)
a) Support to young and midlevel Researchers
Sida-supported young researcher grants are highly sought after as this not only gives young scientists a seed grant for their projects but also familiarizes them with competitive grant winning process. The support is catalytic, and many of the winners from the previous rounds have gone on to win larger grants with the data generated from these projects. Many others have managed to attain enrolment for Masters and PhD degrees analyzing data generated from the Sida-funded projects. Building on this successful programme, icddr,b launched a similar call for female researchers in Bangladesh (both at icddr,b and beyond) in 2020 with the matching grant provided by the Government of Bangladesh to icddr,b for its Hilton Humanitarian Prize won in 2017. The objective of this call is to encourage female scientists in Bangladesh to pursue their career in science and research.
Besides conducting research in Bangladesh, icddr,b has increased its collaboration with research institutions in the global South, leading and participating in research studies in other low-income countries. These collaborations also benefit the development of younger researchers offering opportunities for Masters and PhD studies.
The research funds were also used for hiring a strategically important position of Lead, Research Administration (RA), a core position that has been difficult to fill due to shortage of core resources. RA has been managing Sida grant historically and have been conducting the allocation of Sida funds based on a competitive peer-review process very successfully, which has been recognized not only by the young researchers at icddr,b but also by the Board, Senior Advisory Group (SAG) and senior management of icddr,b. As a result of this, icddr,b launched the competitive grant for the young female researchers mentioned above.
The ongoing projects financed by Sida are very interesting, for example Exploring the challenges and facilitators of implementation of an Information Communication and Technology (ICT)-based human resources management tool in the government health sector in Bangladesh, which was published in BMJ Open. The PI of this protocol was also awarded a Speakers Scholarship at the 6th Global Symposium on Health Systems Research. Oral presentation on the findings from this project were also presented at the Canadian Health Workforce Virtual Conference late 2020.
One of the systematic reviews done on the project Characterizing the Environmental Burden of E-waste and their Impact on children and adult Health has been accepted by the Lancet Planetary Health and other manuscripts are under preparation. The publication was shared broadly, not the least in connection to COP26.
Trainings were organized by icddr,bs Technical Training Unit (TTU) and the Talent Development (TD) units of icddr,b and the topics were selected from the Training Needs Assessment done every year while measuring staff performance. Training was transformed into virtual events instead, and 219 (male: 52%, female: 48%) participants attended through 10 training events.
When Bangladesh caught up with the Covid-19 pandemic, icddr,bs management with approval from Sida decided to re-allocate available funding for these two timely initiatives: 1) Optimizing the treatment of COVID-19 adults with severe pneumonia and/or ARDS in Bangladesh using an adaptive version of locally made Bubble CPAP; and 2) Clinical evaluation of a point-of-need diagnostic system for detection of COVID-19 towards its deployment at peripheral health care settings. Both projects were slow to start but are up and running with promising results. One reason for the delay is that shops and manufacturers closed down, and it wasnt possible to develop adult-sized Bubble-CPAP instruments soon enough.
b) Support to the development of bubble CPAP
Stages I (feasibility, acceptability and operational challenge in two tertiary hospitals) and II (feasibility, acceptability and operational challenge in two district hospitals) were completed with encouraging results in favour of the innovative low-cost bubble CPAP oxygen therapy in treating children with severe pneumonia and hypoxemia. Stage III is ongoing in Ethiopia and will hopefully be finalised in September 2022.
c) ASOOC conference 2020
The 15th Asian Conference on Diarrhoeal Diseases and Nutrition (ASCODD) was held in Dhaka in January 2020 targeting two major problems of enteric diseases both of which are vaccine preventable. The theme of the conference was Typhoid, Cholera, other enteric diseases and their relationship to nutritional disorders: Persisting challenges for LMICs in an era of humanitarian crisis. Sida provided funds for young researchers from low-income countries and partners countries who have Swedish bilateral cooperation in Africa and Asia to attend this conference.
2. Strategic Funding (INTEM/SOCIAL)
The grant has enabled preservation and building of capacity, both primary, secondary and systematic research, analysis and reviews, some leading to publications, as well as reading about development of south-south cooperation in different forms. While the support as such, during both Covid-19 circumstances and a relatively short period did not generate any piece of breakthrough science, the support has contributed to icddr,b's work for better and more permanent integration of thematics by harmonising the process of collecting, curating and communicating data findings across the existing Health and Demographic Surveillance System platforms in line with icddr,b's board's strategic plan and forward vision.
A number of research findings are reported. Icddr,b reports that on a per capita basis, the production of research papers in the Sida-supported groups was significantly higher than the general level of icddr,b production, and grant proposals and concept notes were produced at a creditable rate.
The training courses were designed under two broad themes: (i) Introduction to Epidemiology and Quantitative Research and (ii) Orientation to Implementation Research.
The grant supported primary research. Four research protocols were developed with the aim of assessing the impact of Covid-19 on health systems, gender, food systems and government telemedicine services. In addition, the service quality of the government's telemedicine call-centre (ShasthoBatayon) was assessed, with a particular focus on the centres response to Covid-19. A cross-sectional study was undertaken to understand the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on the food environment, mental health, and related health-seeking behavior, as well as the feasibility of practicing recommended Covid-19 prevention measures among the urban poor. Efforts of government and non-government organizations to address Intimate Partner Violence during Covid-19 in Bangladesh were examined.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
